questions.text:
Arrange the following in sequence? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Crowning
  2. Engagement
  3. Restitution
  4. External rotation
questions.solution:
Ans. A) B, A, C, D

 

Explanation:

 

The sequence of cardinal movements in the mechanism of labor is a series of positions and motions that the fetus goes through as it navigates through the birth canal. These movements are:

 

  1. Engagement: This is when the fetal head enters the pelvic inlet and the widest part of the head has passed through the pelvic brim.
  2. Descent: The downward movement of the fetal head within the pelvic inlet.
  3. Flexion: The fetal head bends so the chin is brought closer to the chest, presenting the smallest diameter to the birth canal.
  4. Internal Rotation: The fetal head rotates to align with the maternal pelvis.
  5. Crowning: The fetal head is visible at the vulva without slipping back.
  6. Extension: The fetal head extends as it passes under the symphysis pubis.
  7. Restitution: The fetal head rotates to the position it was in when it engaged in the pelvis.
  8. External Rotation: The fetal shoulders rotate to align with the head.
  9. Expulsion of the rest of the body: The remainder of the fetal body is delivered.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. B, A, D, C: This sequence incorrectly places external rotation before restitution.

 

Option C. B, C, A, D: This sequence incorrectly places restitution before crowning.

 

Option D. B, D, A, C: This sequence incorrectly places external rotation before crowning and restitution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cardinal movements in the mechanism of labor occur in the following sequence: engagement, descent, flexion, internal rotation, extension (preceded by crowning), restitution, external rotation, and expulsion of the rest of the body.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 145

questions.text: Following delivery at a PHC, a patient was referred with the following image. On examination, there is a tear extending to the rectum. Identify the type of tear. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4th degree


Perineal tears are classified based on the extent of tissue damage during childbirth:

 

  1. 1st degree: Involves only the vaginal mucosa or skin of the perineum without involving deeper tissues.
  2. 2nd degree: Extends deeper, involving the perineal muscles but does not reach the anal sphincters; similar to an episiotomy.
  3. 3rd degree: Involves the anal sphincter complex with further sub-classifications:
    • 3a: Less than 50% of the external anal sphincter is torn.
    • 3b: More than 50% of the external anal sphincter is torn.
    • 3c: Both the external and internal anal sphincters are involved.
  4. 4th degree: Extends through the rectal mucosa, completely disrupting the sphincters and the rectal lining.

 

Since the tear extends to the rectum, this is classified as a 4th degree tear, the most severe type, involving the entire perineum, anal sphincters, and rectal mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:


A 4th degree tear involves disruption of the anal sphincters and rectal mucosa, making it the most severe form of perineal tear during childbirth.

choices.text: Starts after peak of uterine contraction and ends after uterine contraction ends
﻿﻿﻿At least 10 beats, 2 times in a 20 min period above baseline

questions.text: Which statement is false regarding late decelerations? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) At least 10 beats, 2 times in a 20 min period above baseline

 

Explanation:

 

Incorrect. Late decelerations are defined by a decrease in fetal heart rate that is typically more than 15 beats per minute below the baseline and is not defined by a specific frequency above baseline. The characteristic depth and timing of the deceleration are more important than the number of beats or frequency above the baseline.

 

Late decelerations in fetal heart rate patterns are important indicators of fetal well-being and uteroplacental function. late decelerations are indicative of uteroplacental insufficiency. Understanding their characteristics is crucial for accurate assessment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Starts after peak of uterine contraction and ends after uterine contraction ends: Correct. Late decelerations start after the peak of the uterine contraction and end after the contraction has concluded. This delayed onset and resolution are key features.

 

Option B. They are smooth and gradual: Correct. Late decelerations are characterized by a smooth and gradual decline in fetal heart rate (FHR).

 

Option D. Not associated with accelerations: Correct. Late decelerations are not typically associated with accelerations. This differentiates them from other types of decelerations, such as early decelerations, which can be accompanied by accelerations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Late decelerations are characterized by a smooth, gradual decline in fetal heart rate that begins after the peak of a uterine contraction and returns to baseline after the contraction ends, and they are not defined by beats above baseline or associated with accelerations.

 

Ref: Page 693, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

choices.text: 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix

questions.text: All of the following are the diagnostic criteria for preterm labor except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cervix posterior in position

 

Explanation:

 

Preterm labor (PTL) is labor that occurs before the 37th week of gestation. Accurate diagnosis involves evaluating several key criteria:

 

  • Contractions: At least one regular contraction every 10 minutes, or 4 contractions in 20 minutes, or 8 contractions in 60 minutes, with or without pain.
  • Cervical Changes: Cervical dilation greater than 2 cm and more than 80% effacement are significant indicators of preterm labor.

 

The incorrect statement is Option D. A cervix that is posterior in position is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor. Instead, the cervix's position may be less relevant than its dilation and effacement in the diagnosis of preterm labor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix: Correct. Regular contractions that meet the criteria of 4 in 20 minutes or 8 in 60 minutes, along with changes in the cervix, are used to diagnose preterm labor.

 

Option B. Cervical dilatation > 2 cm: Correct. Cervical dilation greater than 2 cm is a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor.

 

Option C. More than 80 percent effaced cervix: Correct. Cervical effacement greater than 80% is another diagnostic criterion for preterm labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cervix being in a posterior position is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor. The diagnosis involves assessing contraction patterns and cervical changes such as dilation and effacement.

 

Ref: Page no 366, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text:
Consider the following actions under AMTSL. Arrange them in the right order? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Uterine tone assessment
  2. Give uterotonic (oxytocin 10 mg)
  3. Exclude the presence of another fetus
  4. Controlled cord traction

 

AMTSL- Active management of the third stage of labor.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3, 2, 4, 1

 

Active Management of 3rd Stage of Labor

 

Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) is a set of interventions aimed at preventing postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). The correct order of actions is:

 

3. Exclude the presence of another fetus: Ensure there is no additional fetus before administering any uterotonic.

 

2. Give uterotonic (oxytocin 10 mg): Administer a uterotonic drug to help the uterus contract and reduce bleeding. It is given after the delivery of baby.

 

4. Controlled cord traction: Perform controlled traction on the umbilical cord to deliver the placenta.

 

1. Uterine tone assessment: assess the uterine tone every 15 minutes to detect uterine atony.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The steps of Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) should be followed in a specific order: exclude the presence of another fetus, administer a uterotonic, perform controlled cord traction, and then assess the uterine tone.

choices.text: Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Internal iliac artery
Uterine artery - Ovarian artery- External iliac artery
Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Vaginal artery
Uterine artery - pudendal artery - Vaginal artery

questions.text: A patient developed atonic postpartum hemorrhage after a normal vaginal delivery. She was shifted to the OT and the obstetrician planned ligation of vessels to arrest the bleeding. What is the order of ligation of the blood vessels supplying the uterus? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Uterine artery – Ovarian artery – Internal iliac artery

 

  • Stepwise devascularization in the management of atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) involves:
    1. Ligation of the uterine arteries:
      • The ascending branch of the uterine artery is ligated at the lateral border between the upper and lower uterine segments.
    2. Ligation of the ovarian and uterine artery anastomoses:
      • Done just below the ovarian ligament.
      • Sometimes, temporary occlusion of the ovarian vessels may be achieved using rubber sleeved clamps.
    3. Ligation of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery:
      • This step reduces blood flow by decreasing the pulse pressure by 85%.
      • Ligation can be unilateral or bilateral.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - External iliac artery: The external iliac artery is not typically involved in the stepwise devascularization for managing atonic PPH.

 

Option C. Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Vaginal artery: Ligation of the vaginal artery is not part of the typical sequence in managing atonic PPH.

 

Option D. Uterine artery - pudendal artery - Vaginal artery: The pudendal artery and vaginal artery are not typically targeted in the stepwise devascularization for atonic PPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stepwise devascularization approach for managing atonic postpartum hemorrhage includes ligation of the uterine arteries, ovarian arteries, and anterior division of the internal iliac arteries in that specific order.

 

Ref: Page no 2023, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: 200 mg

questions.text: The maximum dose of PGF2 alpha in postpartum hemorrhage is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 mg

 

Explanation:

 

Prostaglandin F2 alpha (PGF2α), also known as carboprost, is used for the treatment of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) due to uterine atony. The therapeutic regimen and maximum dosage are crucial for effective management and patient safety.

 

  • Dose and Administration: The approved dose for treating uterine atony with PGF2α is 0.25 mg administered intramuscularly (IM).
  • Maximum Dose: The maximum cumulative dose is 2 mg. This is achieved by administering a total of 8 doses of 0.25 mg each.
  • Dosing Interval: These doses can be repeated at intervals of 15 to 90 minutes, depending on the clinical response and the patient's condition.

 

Contraindications

 

  • Bronchial Asthma: PGF2α can cause bronchoconstriction, which makes it contraindicated in patients with bronchial asthma.
  • Suspected Amniotic Fluid Embolism: Due to its potential to cause pulmonary airway and vascular constriction, it is also contraindicated in cases of suspected amniotic fluid embolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.25 mg: This is the single dose administered IM but not the cumulative maximum dose.

 

Option C. 20 mg: This dose is excessively high and not clinically recommended or safe.

 

Option D. 200 mg: This dose is not applicable for human use and is far beyond the safe and recommended limits.

 

Educational Objective

 

The maximum dose of prostaglandin F2 alpha in the management of postpartum hemorrhage is 2 mg, administered in 0.25 mg increments intramuscularly.

 

Ref: Page no 480, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: Drug contraindicated in asthma in PPH (Postpartum Hemorrhage) case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carboprost

 

Carboprost is a prostaglandin F2 alpha analog that is commonly used to manage atonic postpartum hemorrhage by inducing strong uterine contractions. However, it is contraindicated in patients with asthma because it can cause bronchoconstriction and exacerbate asthma symptoms.

 

Carboprost is also contraindicated in patients with cardiac arrhythmias due to its potent cardiovascular effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methyl ergometrine: This drug is used for the management of postpartum hemorrhage due to its uterotonic properties, but it does not specifically affect asthma and is not contraindicated in asthmatic patients.

 

Option C. Misoprostol: Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, is also used in postpartum hemorrhage for uterine contraction. It does not have the same bronchoconstrictive effects as Carboprost and is not contraindicated in asthma.

 

Option D. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is a common uterotonic agent used in postpartum hemorrhage management. It has no known bronchoconstrictive properties and is safe for use in asthmatic patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carboprost (PGF2 alpha) is contraindicated in patients with asthma due to its bronchoconstrictive effects.

choices.text: Rupture membranes and confirm cord prolapse
Put the cord above the vertex

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is in labor. The cervix is 3 cm dilated and 70% effaced. A "bag of worms" is felt. What is the next best step? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emergency LSCS

 

The description "bag of worms" suggests a cord prolapse, a critical situation where the umbilical cord precedes the fetus, risking compression. An emergency lower segment caesarean section (LSCS) is vital to prevent fetal distress or demise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rupture membranes and confirm cord prolapse: Rupturing membranes could worsen cord compression.

 

Option C. Put the cord above the vertex: Attempting to reposition the cord is risky and generally not recommended.

 

Option D. Wait for spontaneous delivery: Waiting is not advisable due to the risk of cord compression and fetal hypoxia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected cord prolapse during labor, an emergency LSCS is the recommended course of action to safely deliver the baby and minimize the risk of complications.

questions.text: During delivery of a 30y G2P1L1 with previous LSCS, the head was delivered but the shoulders got stuck. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shoulder dystocia

 

Shoulder dystocia is an obstetric emergency where, after the delivery of the fetal head, the shoulders fail to deliver within a typical interval. The definition of shoulder dystocia includes a delivery interval between the head and the shoulders exceeding one minute or requiring specific maneuvers to release the shoulders. This condition occurs when the fetal anterior shoulder impacts behind the maternal pubic symphysis or, less commonly, the posterior shoulder impacts the sacral promontory.

 

In this scenario, the head was delivered, but the shoulders got stuck, fitting the clinical definition of shoulder dystocia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CPD (Cephalopelvic Disproportion): This is incorrect as CPD refers to a mismatch between the size of the fetal head and the maternal pelvis, preventing the fetal head from entering or passing through the birth canal. It does not specifically describe the situation where the shoulders get stuck after the head is delivered.

 

Option C. Occipito posterior: This option is incorrect because it refers to the fetal head being positioned posteriorly in the pelvis, which can cause prolonged labor but does not directly result in shoulder dystocia. In occipito posterior positions, the delivery complication is typically a "face to pubis" delivery, not shoulder entrapment.

 

Option D. Transverse lie: This is incorrect as it describes a fetal position where the fetus lies horizontally in the uterus, which leads to complications like neglected shoulder with hand prolapse if the membranes rupture. The presentation is the shoulder, not the head, which means it does not fit the scenario where the head is delivered but the shoulders are stuck.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shoulder dystocia is diagnosed when the shoulders fail to deliver within a minute after the head or require specific maneuvers for delivery.

questions.text: What is the type of pelvis shown below? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gynecoid Pelvis

 

Explanation:

 

Given image shows a Gynecoid pelvis.

 

Based on the shape of the inlet female pelvis can be divided into 4 types: Gynecoid (50%) Android (25%) Anthropoid (20%) and platypelloid (5%) (Caldwell-Molloy anatomical classification)

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gynecoid pelvis, which is slightly oval or round in the transverse axis, is the most common and ideal type for childbirth.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition page 403, William’s textbook of Obstetrics page 34

questions.text: Oligohydramnios is associated with which of the following? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Renal agenesis

 

Explanation:

 

Early onset oligohydramnios can be due to

 

  •  
  1. Renal anomalies like
    • Bilateral renal agenesis
    • Bilateral dysplastic kidneys
    • Bilateral Autosomal recessive infantile polycystic kidney disease
  2. Preterm prelabor rupture of membranes PPROM)
  3. Drugs like ACE inhibitors or ARB as these cause fetal renal hypoplasia

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neural tube defect: Open Neural tube defects will cause polyhydramnios

 

Option C. Esophageal atresia: Esophageal atresia will cause polyhydramnios

 

Option D. Preterm birth: Preterm birth is seen more commonly in women who have polyhydramnios

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oligohydramnios is associated with renal anomalies such as bilateral renal agenesis, which leads to decreased fetal urine production and a significant reduction in amniotic fluid.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition Page 250,251

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida presented in OBG emergency with 38 weeks of amenorrhea. She is in first stage of labour and on examination, cervical dilatation is 6 cm. According to you, what will be a satisfactory dilatation rate? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1.2 cm/hr

 

Explanation:

 

In a nullipara, 1.2 cm/hr is the best dilatation rate among given options.

 

First stage of labour has 2 phases:

 

 

  • Ideal rate of cervical dilatation in a primi is 1 cm/h
  • Ideal rate of cervical dilatation in a multi is 1.5 cm/h

 

 

The WHO Labour Care guide (2021) differs from the earlier partograph in the following ways:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ideal rate of cervical dilatation in a primi is 1 cm/h

 

Ref: WHO labour care guide Users Manual 2021

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding perimortem cesarean section? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Upper segment cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

An upper segment cesarean section is performed during a perimortem cesarean section (PMCS). PMCS is an emergency cesarean delivery of a woman who is expected to die within the next few moments or has just died.

 

Key points about PMCS:

 

  • Timing: According to the AHA 2020 Guidelines for CPR, perimortem cesarean should be considered if there is no return of spontaneous circulation within 5 minutes in a pregnant woman who has experienced total cardiopulmonary arrest.
  • Purpose: The goal of PMCS is to improve maternal and fetal outcomes by relieving the compression of the inferior vena cava (IVC) by the gravid uterus, which enhances venous return and diaphragmatic displacement. This, in turn, improves respiratory dynamics and resuscitative efforts.
  • Fetal Outcome: The infant has a higher chance of survival if PMCS is performed within 10 minutes of maternal death.
  • Surgical Technique: A classical upper-segment cesarean section with a vertical uterine incision is performed.
  • Location: PMCS does not need to be done in the operating theatre (OT); it can be done wherever the patient is located to expedite the process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LSCS: Lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) is not typically used in PMCS.

 

Option B. Pfannenstiel incision: This is a horizontal incision typically used in elective cesarean sections, not in emergency PMCS.

 

Option D. Done in OT: PMCS does not need to be performed in the operating theatre; it can be done immediately at the site of the patient to save time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perimortem cesarean section (PMCS) involves performing a classical upper-segment cesarean section with a vertical uterine incision in an emergency situation to improve maternal and fetal outcomes.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK459265/

questions.text: Identify the maneuver? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Burn Marshall

 

The Burns Marshall maneuver is a technique used during breech deliveries. This maneuver involves gently swinging the baby over the maternal abdomen by holding the baby's ankles. The purpose is to facilitate the delivery of the after-coming head in breech presentation. It requires careful handling to avoid neck injury and to maintain control during delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wigand: The Wigand maneuver is another technique used in obstetrics, but it is not related to breech delivery or involves swinging the baby over the maternal abdomen.

 

Option C. Mauriceau Smellie Viet: This maneuver is used during breech delivery but involves supporting the baby's body on the obstetrician's forearm with the index and middle fingers placed on the maxilla to flex the head. It does not involve swinging the baby and is distinct from the Burns Marshall maneuver.

 

 

Option D. Prague: The Prague maneuver is used in breech delivery, specifically when the baby's arms are extended above the head. The obstetrician rotates the baby to facilitate arm delivery before the head, differing from the Burns Marshall maneuver.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Burns Marshall maneuver is characterized by gently swinging the baby over the maternal abdomen to assist in the delivery of the after-coming head in breech presentation.

questions.text: What is given to prevent neural tube defects? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Folic acid

 

Folic acid supplementation is essential for the prevention of neural tube defects (NTDs) in the developing fetus. Neural tube defects are severe birth defects of the brain and spine, such as spina bifida and anencephaly, that occur when the neural tube does not close completely. Folic acid, a B-vitamin, significantly reduces the risk of these defects when taken in adequate amounts before conception and during early pregnancy.

 

It is recommended that women start taking folic acid atleast three months before conception and continue through the first three months of pregnancy.

 

For women at low risk, the recommended dose is 0.4 to 0.5 mg per day.

 

For those at high risk, including women with a previous pregnancy affected by NTDs, known folate deficiency, overt diabetes mellitus, or those on anti-epileptic drugs, the recommended dose is 4 to 5 mg per day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron: This option is incorrect as iron supplementation is used primarily to prevent and treat anemia in pregnancy, not to prevent neural tube defects.

 

Option B. Calcium: This is incorrect because calcium is important for the development of the fetal skeletal system and for maternal bone health, but it does not prevent neural tube defects.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12: This option is incorrect as vitamin B12, while important for overall neurological health, is not the primary supplement used to prevent neural tube defects. However, B12 works synergistically with folic acid, and deficiency in B12 can contribute to NTDs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folic acid supplementation before conception and during early pregnancy is crucial to prevent neural tube defects in the developing fetus.

questions.text: A 28-year primigravida is in labor. She has a repeated urge to pass urine and has premature bearing down. On examination there is infra-umbilical flattening, and the fetal heart is heard on the lateral side. What is the most likely presentation/ position? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Occipito-posterior

 

Explanation:

 

Occipito-posterior:

 

  • History:
    • Early rupture of membranes.
    • Frequent filling of bladder.
    • Premature bearing down.
  • Abdominal Examination:
    • Inspection: Infra-umbilical flattening, which indicates that the fetus is not positioned centrally in the uterus.
    • Grips: The fetal head is un-engaged, which is often the case with occipito-posterior positions.
    • Auscultation: Fetal heart sounds (FHS) are heard on the flanks, suggesting that the fetus is lying posteriorly.
  • Vaginal Examination:
    • An elongated bag of membranes.
    • The posterior fontanelle is near the sacro-iliac joint.
    • The anterior fontanelle is more easily felt due to deflexion of the fetal head.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knee: A knee presentation is a form of breech presentation where the knees are the presenting part. It is rare and would not cause infra-umbilical flattening or lateral fetal heart sounds.

 

Option C. Brow: The brow presentation involves partial extension of the fetal head. The presenting diameter is larger, leading to a more difficult labor. However, this would not typically present with infra-umbilical flattening or lateral fetal heart sounds.

 

Option D. Right dorso-anterior: This position involves the fetus's back being to the mother's right and anterior. It would not cause infra-umbilical flattening and lateral fetal heart sounds like the occipito-posterior position does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The occipito-posterior position in labor is characterized by infra-umbilical flattening, frequent filling of the bladder, premature bearing down, and fetal heart sounds heard on the lateral side.

 

 

Ref: Page no 302, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3rd edition

questions.text: What is the dose of carbetocin used in the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 100 mcg

 

  • 100 mcg of carbetocin is used in the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).
  • The use of carbetocin (100 mcg, IM/IV) is recommended for the prevention of PPH.
  • It is a long-acting synthetic analog of oxytocin which is stable at room temperature (unlike oxytocin which needs the cold chain to be maintained.
  • To effectively prevent PPH, the WHO recommends the use of only one of the following uterotonic agents:
    • Oxytocin (10 IU - IM/IV)
    • Carbetocin (100 ug - IM/IV)
    • Misoprostol (400 g or 600 g, per-oral)
    • Ergometrine/methylergometrine (200 ug - IM/IV)
    • Oxytocin and ergometrine fixed-dose combination (5 IU,500g - IM)
  • Of these, oxytocin is used as the first-line agent (drug of choice) for AMTSL.

 

Educational Objective:


The recommended dose of carbetocin for the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage is 100 mcg, administered either IM or IV.

choices.text: 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
6 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
4 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
Midway between the anterior and posterior fontanelle

questions.text: You are applying a vacuum to deliver a baby in a patient with prolonged 2nd stage. The point at which the vacuum is applied is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle

 

The Ans. is 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle, which is the location known as the flexion point. The flexion point is critical in vacuum-assisted deliveries because it lies 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle on the baby's head. This point is chosen because pulling on this location causes flexion of the baby's head, facilitating the proper positioning for delivery. Flexion is crucial as it allows the smallest diameter of the baby's head to present, making the delivery process smoother and safer for both the mother and baby.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flexion point, located 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle, is the optimal site for applying a vacuum during delivery to achieve the necessary head flexion.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication to the procedure shown? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primigravida

 

The procedure shown is an External Cephalic Version (ECV), a technique used to turn a breech fetus to a cephalic (head-down) position before labor to facilitate a vaginal delivery. While it is generally more challenging to perform ECV in primigravida (first-time pregnant women) due to a tenser abdominal wall, it is not a contraindication. The procedure can still be performed in primigravida with caution and proper monitoring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta previa: This is a definite contraindication to ECV because the placenta covers the cervix, preventing safe vaginal delivery. Attempting ECV in such cases could cause placental abruption or severe bleeding, necessitating a cesarean section regardless.

 

Option C. Multiple pregnancy: ECV is contraindicated in multiple pregnancies (twins or more) because manipulating one fetus could adversely affect the position of the other, making the procedure unsafe.

 

Option D. Ruptured membranes: When membranes are ruptured, there is a loss of amniotic fluid (liquor), which is necessary for the maneuverability of the fetus during ECV. Without sufficient amniotic fluid, the procedure is difficult, risky, and not feasible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primigravida is not a contraindication for ECV, though it may be technically more challenging compared to multiparous women. Key contraindications to ECV include placenta previa, multiple pregnancy, and ruptured membranes.

questions.text: A primigravida presented to the labor room at 38 weeks. At 1 pm she is 5 cm dilated. After 4 hours she is 6 cm dilated. What is the next best step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ARM + oxytocin

 

Explanation:

 

The patient is experiencing protracted labor, as indicated by a slow progression in cervical dilation (only 1 cm increase in 4 hours). In active labor, the cervix is expected to dilate at a rate of approximately 1 cm per hour. Here, the cervix dilated from 5 cm to 6 cm in 4 hours, indicating a slow or protracted dilation phase.

 

Management of Protracted Labor:

 

Assessment: Evaluate the cause of slow labor, which could be due to issues with powers (uterine contractions), the passage (pelvis), or the passenger (fetal position or presentation).

 

Augmentation of Labor:

 

  • 1st step: ARM (Artificial Rupture of Membranes): This can help enhance uterine contractions and allow assessment of the amniotic fluid for the presence of meconium, which could indicate fetal distress.
  • 2nd step: Oxytocin: If contractions remain inadequate after ARM, oxytocin can be administered to strengthen uterine contractions and accelerate labor progress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait for 4 hours and reexamine: This is not recommended as it allows prolonged labor to continue without intervention, increasing the risk of complications.

 

Option B. LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section): While a cesarean section may be necessary if augmentation fails or if there are other indications, it is not the immediate next step without attempting augmentation.

 

Option D. Forceps delivery: Forceps can only be applied when the cervix is fully dilated (10 cm), not at 6 cm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a primigravida with protracted labor (slow cervical dilation), the next best step is to perform artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) and administer oxytocin to augment labor and promote adequate uterine contractions.

questions.text: During delivery of a 24 y primigravida, the head comes out, but the shoulders fail to deliver. McRoberts maneuver is immediately done but the shoulders still fail to deliver. What is the next best step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Supra-pubic pressure

 

Explanation:

 

In cases of shoulder dystocia, where the baby's shoulders fail to deliver after the head, specific maneuvers are performed in a stepwise manner. The McRoberts maneuver, which involves hyperflexion and abduction of the mother's thighs onto her abdomen, is the first step and is successful in resolving many cases by reducing the angle of the pelvis.

 

If the McRoberts maneuver is unsuccessful, the next step is to apply supra-pubic pressure. This involves an assistant applying pressure just above the pubic bone to help dislodge the anterior shoulder from behind the pubic symphysis. This maneuver is often performed simultaneously with the McRoberts maneuver but is listed next in the shoulder dystocia drill.

 

HELPER mnemonic from Baxley and Gobbo, 2004, is a guideline for managing obstetric emergencies:

 

  • H: Call for Help
  • E: Evaluate for Episiotomy
  • L: Legs (The McRoberts manoeuvre)
  • P: Suprapubic Pressure
  • E: Enter manoeuvres (internal rotation)
  • R: Remove the posterior arm
  • R: Roll the patient (Gaskin maneuver)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delivery of the posterior shoulder: This is a subsequent step if supra-pubic pressure and internal rotation maneuver fail.

 

Option B. Internal rotation: This includes maneuver like the Woods corkscrew or Rubin maneuver and is considered after supra-pubic pressure fails.

 

Option D. Zavanelli maneuver: This is a last-resort measure where the baby's head is pushed back into the birth canal for an emergency cesarean section.

 

Educational objective:

 

If the McRoberts maneuver fails to resolve shoulder dystocia, the next step is to apply supra-pubic pressure to help dislodge the anterior shoulder.

questions.text: The ideal number of ANC visits is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 12-15

 

Antenatal care (ANC) visits are crucial for monitoring the health of both the mother and the fetus during pregnancy. Different guidelines recommend varying numbers of visits:

 

  • Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (India): Recommends at least 4 visits.
  • World Health Organization (WHO): Suggests 8 visits, referring to them as "contacts."
  • American guidelines and practical recommendations: Advise 12-15 visits, ensuring comprehensive care.

 

The ideal number of ANC visits, according to American guidelines and actual practice, is 12-15. This schedule is designed to closely monitor the pregnancy and promptly address any complications:

 

  • Monthly visits until 28 weeks of gestation.
  • Bi-weekly visits from 28 to 36 weeks.
  • Weekly visits from 36 weeks until delivery.

 

This frequency allows for timely detection and management of potential issues, ensuring the best outcomes for both mother and baby.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ideal number of ANC visits is 12-15, as recommended by American guidelines, to ensure comprehensive prenatal care.

choices.text: Mandatory episiotomy
Manual perineal support and warm compresses
Maintain head in deflexion and deliver
Deliver in lithotomy position only

questions.text: Which of the following is recommended by the WHO for the management of the second stage of labor? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Manual perineal support and warm compresses


The WHO guidelines for managing the second stage of labor emphasize techniques to reduce perineal trauma and enhance maternal comfort. The use of manual perineal support and warm compresses is recommended to protect the perineum during delivery and reduce the incidence of severe perineal tears.

 

  • Manual Perineal Support and Warm Compresses:
    • Manual Support: Hands-on guarding of the perineum during delivery helps control the speed of delivery and reduces the risk of severe perineal tears.
    • Warm Compresses: Applying warm compresses to the perineum can help relax the tissues and make them more pliable, further reducing the risk of tearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mandatory Episiotomy: Not Recommended: Routine episiotomy is no longer recommended by the WHO. It is only indicated in specific cases where it is necessary to expedite delivery for the safety of the mother or baby.

 

Option C. Maintain Head in Deflexion and Deliver: Not Recommended: The recommendation is to allow the fetal head to assume the most optimal position for delivery rather than intentionally maintaining deflexion, which may hinder the delivery process.

 

Option D. Deliver in Lithotomy Position Only: Not Recommended: The WHO supports a variety of birthing positions based on the mother’s preference and comfort. Restricting delivery to the lithotomy position is not recommended; instead, women should be encouraged to choose their preferred position.

 

Educational Objective:


Manual perineal support and warm compresses are recommended by the WHO to reduce perineal trauma during the second stage of labor.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/337693/9789240017566-eng.pdf

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in the vertex presentation with complete flexion attitude of head? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Suboccipito-bregmatic diameter

 

Explanation:

 

Suboccipito-bregmatic diameter (9.5 cm) is seen in vertex presentation with a complete flexion attitude of the head.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Suboccipito-frontal diameter:

 

  • This diameter measures about 10.5 cm and is seen when the head is only partially flexed.
  • It is not the smallest diameter and is not optimal for vertex presentations with complete flexion.

 

Option C. Occipito-frontal diameter:

 

  • This diameter measures approximately 11.5 cm and is seen in cases where the head is in a neutral position, neither fully flexed nor extended.
  • It is larger and more difficult for the passage of the fetal head through the birth canal.

 

Option D. Occipito-posterior position:

 

  • This is not a diameter but a fetal position where the back of the fetal head is directed towards the mother's back.
  • This position often leads to a more difficult labor and is associated with different presenting diameters, depending on the degree of head flexion or extension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The suboccipito-bregmatic diameter (9.5 cm) is seen in vertex presentation with complete flexion of the fetal head, facilitating easier passage through the birth canal.

 

Ref: Page no   92 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

choices.text: Remove the placenta and reposition the uterus
Reposition the uterus with the placenta attached

questions.text: A 27y primigravida has just delivered. When removing the placenta, uterine inversion is noted. What is the next immediate step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Reposition the uterus with the placenta attached

 

Explanation:

 

Uterine inversion is a rare but serious obstetric emergency that occurs when the uterus turns inside out after delivery. Immediate management is crucial to prevent severe hemorrhage and shock. The next immediate step in the management of uterine inversion is to manually reposition the uterus with the placenta still attached. This is done to quickly restore the uterus to its normal position and reduce the risk of continued bleeding and shock.

 

 

After manually repositioning the uterus, the healthcare provider should maintain the position by keeping a fist inside the uterus and administering uterotonic agents such as oxytocin to promote uterine contractions, which help to keep the uterus in place and reduce bleeding. The placenta should only be removed after the uterus has been repositioned successfully.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shift to OT immediately: While surgical intervention may be required if manual repositioning fails, the initial step is to manually reposition the uterus.

 

Option B. Remove the placenta and reposition the uterus: Removing the placenta before repositioning the uterus can lead to increased bleeding and is not recommended.

 

Option D. O'Sullivan's hydrostatic maneuver: This maneuver involves using fluid pressure to reposition the uterus and is used if manual repositioning fails. It is not the immediate next step.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The immediate step in managing uterine inversion is to manually reposition the uterus with the placenta still attached, followed by administration of uterotonic agents to maintain the uterus in its correct position.

questions.text: Following delivery, the placenta is being removed by traction on the  cord as shown in the image. The cord snaps and there is profuse bleeding. What is the next step in management?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Manual removal of placenta

 

  • Manual removal of placenta:
    • The maneuver shown in the image is the Brandt-Andrews maneuver, used in controlled cord traction for the delivery of the placenta.
    • If the umbilical cord snaps during this maneuver, it indicates a retained placenta, which can lead to profuse bleeding.
    • The immediate next step is manual removal of the placenta to prevent excessive hemorrhage and ensure that no parts of the placenta remain in the uterus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxytocin: While oxytocin is used to enhance uterine contractions and prevent postpartum hemorrhage, in this scenario, it is more critical to address the retained placenta immediately through manual removal.

 

Option B. Uterine massage: Uterine massage is beneficial in promoting uterine contractions and reducing bleeding, but it will not resolve the issue of the retained placenta.

 

Option C. Arrange blood and Crede’s method: Arranging blood is prudent for managing potential blood loss, but Crede’s method, which involves expulsion of the placenta by fundal pressure, is not recommended due to the risk of uterine inversion and other complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When the umbilical cord snaps during controlled cord traction for placenta delivery, manual removal of the placenta is the immediate next step to prevent hemorrhage and ensure complete removal.

 

Ref: Page 1298, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Start colloids initially, 4 times the blood lost
Primary PPH occurs within 24 hours of childbirth
PPH is loss of > 500 ml of blood in vaginal delivery
Causes include retained placenta and atony

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding post-partum hemorrhage (PPH)? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Start colloids initially, 4 times the blood lost

 

The false statement regarding post-partum hemorrhage (PPH) is option A. The standard practice for managing PPH is to start intravenous isotonic crystalloids rather than colloids. Colloids are generally reserved for specific situations and are not the initial choice for fluid resuscitation in PPH. The correct approach involves using crystalloids to replace lost blood volume. The recommendation is not to administer colloids at a volume four times the amount of blood lost.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primary PPH occurs within 24 hours of childbirth: This statement is true. Primary or early postpartum hemorrhage refers to blood loss occurring within the first 24 hours after delivery.

 

Option C. PPH is loss of > 500 ml of blood in vaginal delivery: This statement is true. Postpartum hemorrhage is defined as a blood loss greater than 500 ml following a vaginal delivery and more than 1000 ml following a cesarean section.

 

Option D. Causes include retained placenta and atony: This statement is true. Common causes of postpartum hemorrhage include uterine atony (failure of the uterus to contract) and retained placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Initial management of post-partum hemorrhage should involve intravenous isotonic crystalloids, not colloids.

 

Ref: Page 1894, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary PPH? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Placenta previa

 

Explanation:

 

Placenta previa is not a cause of secondary postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). It is primarily associated with antepartum hemorrhage (bleeding before delivery) and is a risk factor for primary PPH (occurring within the first 24 hours after childbirth).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Retained cotyledon: Retained cotyledon can lead to secondary PPH due to retained placental fragments, causing continued uterine bleeding.

 

Option B. Endometritis: Endometritis, an infection of the uterine lining, can cause secondary PPH by leading to inflammation and impaired uterine contraction.

 

Option C. Placental polyp: A placental polyp, which is retained placental tissue that forms a growth, can cause secondary PPH through persistent bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placenta previa is a cause of antepartum hemorrhage and primary postpartum hemorrhage but not secondary postpartum hemorrhage.

 

Ref: Page no 804, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: All are causes of uterine dysfunction, except: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multiparity

 

Explanation:

 

  • Multiparity is not a cause of uterine dysfunction; rather, nulliparity (the condition of a woman who has never given birth) is a recognized cause. Uterine dysfunction, particularly hypotonic uterine dysfunction, is associated with several factors, but multiparity is generally associated with a more efficient labor process due to the body's previous experience with childbirth.

 

Causes of hypotonic uterine dysfunction:

 

  • Neuraxial analgesia: The use of epidural or spinal anesthesia can interfere with uterine contractions.
  • Chorioamnionitis: This is an infection of the amniotic fluid and membranes, which can lead to inflammation and impaired uterine contractility.
  • Nulliparity: First-time mothers (nulliparous women) are more likely to experience uterine dysfunction due to the unconditioned nature of the uterine muscles.
  • Other factors:
    • Mechanical disruption of myometrial function by a fibroid or pelvic tumor
    • Maternal obesity
    • Uterine mullerian anomaly
    • Increased maternal age
    • Malposition and malpresentation of the fetus
    • Contracted pelvis

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Chorioamnionitis: Chorioamnionitis, an infection, can impair uterine contractions and lead to dysfunctional labor.

 

Option C. High fetal head station: High fetal head station can be associated with labor dystocia and uterine dysfunction as it may indicate issues with the descent of the baby.

 

Option D. Neuraxial blockade: Neuraxial block (e.g., epidural) can interfere with effective uterine contractions, leading to uterine dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nulliparity, not multiparity, is a cause of uterine dysfunction. Causes of hypotonic uterine dysfunction include neuraxial analgesia, chorioamnionitis, nulliparity, and mechanical factors such as fibroids or pelvic tumors.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg459, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 416

choices.text: Normal vaginal delivery
Forceps delivery

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the emergency room in the early stage of labor with adequate uterine contractions. On per vaginal examination, a gynecoid pelvis is felt, the membranes are ruptured, and the vertex is felt in the right occipito-posterior position. How will you manage this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal vaginal delivery

 

Explanation:

 

  • Normal vaginal delivery:
    • Assuming the patient has no other complications, such as fetal distress or cephalopelvic disproportion, the given features of right occipito-posterior presentation with a favorable pelvis (gynecoid) and adequate uterine contractions can be managed by normal vaginal delivery.
    • In 90% of circumstances with a favorable pelvis and strong uterine contractions, without any complications, the occipito-posterior position can undergo the mechanism of normal labor.
    • The patient can be closely monitored for the progress of normal vaginal delivery. However, if complications arise or labor stalls, alternative methods such as vacuum-assisted delivery or forceps delivery may be considered. A cesarean section would only be necessary if there were complications that prevented a safe vaginal delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Vacuum-assisted delivery is generally considered when there is prolonged second stage of labor or fetal distress. In this case, since there are no complications mentioned and the pelvis is favorable, normal vaginal delivery is the preferred option.

 

Option B. Cesarean section: A cesarean section is usually considered when there is cephalopelvic disproportion, fetal distress, or failure to progress in labor. Given the favorable conditions in this scenario, a normal vaginal delivery is feasible.

 

Option D. Forceps delivery: Forceps delivery, like vacuum-assisted delivery, is used in cases of prolonged second stage of labor or when there is a need to expedite delivery. In the absence of such complications, normal vaginal delivery is the appropriate management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right occipito-posterior presentation with a favorable pelvis and adequate uterine contractions in a primigravida can be managed by closely monitoring for a normal vaginal delivery, provided there are no complications.

 

Ref: Page 89, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents to emergency following bleeding per vaginum, preceded by amenorrhea for 7 weeks. She's in hemodynamic shock with a positive serum beta hCG. On examination, a mass is palpable in the lower abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis in this scenario? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rupture ectopic pregnancy

 

Explanation:

 

The above clinical scenario suggests a case of ruptured ectopic pregnancy. Following are the features:

 

  • Positive serum beta hCG: Indicates pregnancy.
  • History of amenorrhea for 7 weeks: Clinical manifestations of ectopic pregnancy typically appear six to eight weeks after the last normal menstrual period.
  • Unstable vitals (hemodynamic shock): Suggestive of hemoperitoneum, a serious complication often seen with ruptured ectopic pregnancy.
  • Mass palpable in the lower abdomen: Could be due to the ectopic pregnancy or associated hemoperitoneum.

 

The classic triad of symptoms of an ectopic pregnancy are:

 

  • Pain
  • Bleeding
  • Amenorrhea

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyelonephritis: While pyelonephritis can cause abdominal pain and fever, it does not typically present with amenorrhea or positive serum beta hCG.

 

Option B. Gastrointestinal stromal tumor: This may cause abdominal pain but does not account for the positive beta hCG or amenorrhea.

 

Option C. Red degeneration of fibroid: This often occurs during pregnancy and can cause abdominal pain, but it is not typically associated with bleeding per vaginum and positive serum beta hCG in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic triad of symptoms for ectopic pregnancy is pain, bleeding, and amenorrhea, with a positive beta hCG test and unstable vitals indicating a possible ruptured ectopic pregnancy.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Page 212

questions.text: Identify the blue-colored area shown in the image below?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mid-pelvis

 

The true pelvis is divided into 3 planes

 

  1. Plane of Inlet
  2. Plane of Mid cavity (Mid-Pelvis)
  3. Plane of Outlet

 

The Plane of Mid Cavity (Or Mid-Pelvis) is what is shown in the image

 

Pelvic Cavity

 

This has 2 planes

 

  1. Plane of Greatest Dimension: 
    • At the level of S2/3
    • Circular plane; AP diameter = Transverse diameter = 12.5 cm
    • Widest part of pelvis
  2. Plane of Least dimension
    • At the level of S3/4
    • At the level of ischial spine
    • Very important plane CLINICALLY
      1. Narrowest part of pelvis
      2. Internal rotation takes place here
      3. Origin of levator ani
      4. Landmark for pudendal block
      5. When engagement occurs, the head is felt at 0 station, i.e., at this plane
      6. Deep Transverse Arrest occurs here

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obstetric outlet:

 

  • Refers to the lower part of the pelvic outlet, which is wider than the anatomical outlet.
  • Not shown in the image.

 

Option B. Anatomical outlet:

 

  • Refers to the narrowest part of the pelvic outlet.
  • Not shown in the image.

 

Option C. Pelvic inlet:

 

  • Marks the entrance to the true pelvis.
  • Not shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The plane of the mid-pelvis (or mid cavity) is a crucial area within the true pelvis, significant for various clinical considerations during labor and delivery.

 

Ref: Page no 92 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

questions.text: A partogram of a woman in labor is shown below. Oxytocin infusion has been administered. Mark the best management for the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

The above partogram suggests that the woman has cephalopelvic disproportion, for which the management would be to perform an emergency caesarean section.

 

According to the above given partogram, findings are

 

  • Cervix is fully dilated
  • Moulding is 2+ = Sutures are overlapped but reducible
  • Station is 3+
  • Oxytocin infusion administered.
  • Uterine contractions - Adequate.
  • Amniotic fluid - M = Meconium-stained fluid
  • Fetal heart rate – Deceleration = Baby is in distress
  • Descent: Head is 3/5th palpable; this means that an instrument cannot be applied. For either forceps of vacuum to be applied, the head should not be palpable per abdomen.

 

In case of fetal distress, the management is an emergency cesarean section, not instrumental delivery or elective cesarean section.

 

Cephalopelvic disproportion means there is a disproportion in the fetal head and pelvis. It could be due to a Contracted pelvis or large baby (Macrosomia)

 

Degrees of Disproportion

 

  1. Severe degree contracted pelvis: Obstetric conjugate < 7.5 cm
  2. Moderate degree: Obstetric conjugate between 7.5 to 9.5 cm
  3. Borderline pelvis: Obstetric conjugate measures between 9.5 to 10 cm

 

Obstructed labor is one where despite good uterine contractions, the progressive descent of the presenting part is arrested due to mechanical obstruction. Cephalopelvic disproportion and contracted pelvis are the common causes.

 

A cesarean section at term is should be done in these cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Forceps-assisted delivery: Not suitable because the head is still palpable per abdomen and forceps cannot be applied.

 

Option B. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Not appropriate due to the same reason as above; the head is still palpable per abdomen.

 

Option C. Oxytocin infusion: Oxytocin infusion is already being administered, and increasing or continuing it won't resolve the issue of cephalopelvic disproportion and fetal distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of cephalopelvic disproportion and fetal distress, as indicated by a partogram, the management should be an emergency cesarean section.

choices.text: Wait for an hour for spontaneous labor

questions.text: You are examining a multigravida in the second stage of labor for the past two hours. On examination, contractions are adequate, the cervix is fully dilated with the head at station 0 with molding 2+ and caput 2+. The sagittal suture is in the right occipito-transverse position. The fetal heart rate is 140 beats/minute. Which of the following is carried out for the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lower segment cesarean section

 

  • The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of deep transverse arrest (DTA)
  • There are features of CPD (Caput 2 + and moulding 2+)
  • Hence, a lower segment cesarean section is carried out for the management of this patient.
  • In deep transverse arrest
    • The sagittal suture is placed in the transverse bispinous diameter.
    • There is no descent of the head despite good uterine contractions
    • The cervix is fully dilated
    • If the pelvis is adequate, application of ventouse or manual rotation and forces application can be tried. (Vacuum is preferred)
    • If signs of CDP/ obstruction: Cesarean section is done

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mid pelvic forceps: Mid pelvic forceps: Cannot be applied in this scenario as there are features of obstructed labor with deep transverse arrest

 

Option B. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Vacuum is an option in deep transverse arrest but only if there is no CPD. With caput ++ and moulding ++, there is likely an element of CPD and obstruction and hence vacuum should not be used

 

Option C. Wait for an hour for spontaneous labor: Waiting and watching is not an option as the patient is already showing features of obstructed labor and she has already been in 2nd stage of labor for 2 hours (upper limit for 2nd stage of labor in primi is 3h and in multi is 2h)

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case of deep transverse arrest with features of CPD, a lower segment cesarean section is the appropriate management to prevent complications and ensure safe delivery.

 

Ref: Page 661, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: The type of pelvis commonly associated with occipitoposterior and face to pubis is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 

 

 

The anthropoid pelvis is characterized by a larger anteroposterior diameter compared to its transverse diameter, giving it a vertical oval shape. This type of pelvis is commonly associated with occipitoposterior positions and the "face to pubis" delivery pattern, where the baby's face presents toward the pubic symphysis during delivery. The anthropoid shape often causes the baby's head to rotate into a posterior position, leading to a higher likelihood of occipitoposterior presentations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gynecoid pelvis: The gynecoid pelvis is the typical female pelvis with a round shape and balanced anteroposterior and transverse diameters. It is most favorable for vaginal deliveries and is not commonly associated with occipitoposterior positions.

 

Option B. Android pelvis: The android pelvis is heart-shaped, narrower, and typically has prominent ischial spines. It is more commonly associated with obstructed labor and deep transverse arrest rather than occipitoposterior or face to pubis presentations.

 

Option D. Platypelloid pelvis: The platypelloid pelvis is characterized by a very wide transverse diameter and a flat shape, which often leads to delayed engagement of the fetal head. It is not associated with occipitoposterior positions but can lead to asynclitism and face presentations.

 

Educational Objective:


The anthropoid pelvis is the pelvic type most commonly associated with occipitoposterior positions and the "face to pubis" delivery pattern.

choices.text: Fetal head 5/5 palpable on abdominal examination
Two contractions lasting for 10 seconds in 10 minutes
More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the labor room at 40 weeks of gestation with lower abdominal pain. She has been in labor for 3 hours. Which of the following will determine if she is in active labor?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement

 

  • More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement:
    • According to the World Health Organization (WHO) Labor Care Guide (LCG), active labor begins at more than 5 cm of cervical dilatation.
    • The older definition of active labor was at 4 cm of cervical dilatation.
    • The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) now defines active labor as beginning at more than 6 cm of cervical dilatation.
    • Complete effacement indicates that the cervix has thinned out, which is a key indicator of active labor progression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal head 5/5 palpable on abdominal examination: This indicates that the fetal head is still high in the pelvis and not yet engaged. It does not determine active labor.

 

Option B. Two contractions lasting for 10 seconds in 10 minutes: This frequency and duration of contractions are not sufficient to determine active labor. Active labor typically involves regular, strong contractions lasting 45-60 seconds and occurring every 2-3 minutes.

 

Option D. Rupture of membranes: While rupture of membranes can occur during labor, it is not a definitive indicator of active labor. Cervical dilation and effacement are more reliable indicators.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Active labor is determined by more than 5 cm of cervical dilatation with complete effacement, according to the WHO Labor Care Guide.

 

Ref: Page no 138, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: Which drug is contraindicated in a patient with atonic PPH with a history of hypertension? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ergotamine

 

Ergotamine (or methylergometrine) is an ergot alkaloid that is commonly used as a uterotonic agent to manage postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) by promoting uterine contractions. However, it has potent vasoconstrictive properties, which significantly increase vascular resistance and blood pressure.

 

In patients with a history of hypertension, the use of ergotamine is contraindicated because its vasoconstrictive effect can lead to a dangerous rise in blood pressure. This increase in afterload can put additional strain on the heart and may precipitate hypertensive crises or other cardiovascular complications. Therefore, ergotamine is avoided in hypertensive patients, particularly in those with chronic hypertension or other cardiovascular diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol: Misoprostol is a prostaglandin E1 analogue that is also used to manage postpartum hemorrhage. It induces uterine contractions but does not have significant vasoconstrictive effects. Therefore, it is not contraindicated in patients with hypertension.

 

Option B. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is another uterotonic agent that works by stimulating uterine contractions. While it can cause mild vasodilation, it does not have the strong vasoconstrictive properties of ergotamine and is generally safe to use in hypertensive patients.

 

Option D. PGF2 alpha: Certain prostaglandins can increase blood pressure and should be used with caution, but they are not as strongly contraindicated as ergotamine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ergotamine is contraindicated in patients with hypertension due to its potent vasoconstrictive effects, which can significantly increase blood pressure and cause cardiovascular complications. This drug should be avoided in hypertensive patients, especially when managing postpartum hemorrhage.

questions.text: A primigravida is in labour. Her per-vaginal examination revealed a posterior cervix with 5 cm cervical length, 1 cm dilatation, soft consistency, and head at -1 station. Calculate the modified Bishop score? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5

 

Explanation:

 

Bishop Score

 

  • This is a scoring system used to assess the favorability of the cervix to respond to induction of labor. 
  • A cervix that is soft in consistency, a little dilated, short in length, anteriorly placed and the station of the presenting low down will respond well to induction of labor. 
  • The Bishop score was replaced by the Modified Bishop score, wherein, the cervical effacement (in terms of percentage) was replaced by cervical length (in cm). 
  • The 5 components of the Modified Bishop score are:
    1. Cervical Dilatation
    2. Cervical length
    3. Cervical consistency
    4. Cervical Position
    5. Station of the presenting part

 

Easy to remember Mnemonic

 

B – Bishop

 

I – Effacement

 

S – Station of presenting part

 

H – Hard/ soft (consistency)

 

O – Os dilatation (cervical dilatation)

 

P – Position of the cervix

 

  • The scoring is as shown in the table.
  • Each component is scored from 0 to 3
  • The highest score is 13 and the lowest is 0
  • A favourable score is > 6. This means the patient will respond favorably to methods of induction of labor. 

 

 

Educational Objective:


The Modified Bishop score is used to assess the cervix's favorability for induction, and a score of 5 in this context would be based on specific factors.

 

Ref: Page no 600, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with obstructed labor and is grossly dehydrated. Investigations reveal fetal demise. What will be the management? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

  • Obstructed labor is a direct indication for an emergency cesarean section
  • Obstructed labor happens when despite good uterine contractions, labor does not progress due to problems in the maternal pelvis/ fetus or a mechanical obstruction
  • Features of Obstructed Labor:
  • Maternal exhaustion and dehydration
  • Abdominal examination
    • Upper segment is tonically contracted with no relaxation The wall becomes thicker
    • Lower segment becomes distended and thinned out
    • Fetal parts not easily felt
    • Round ligaments taut and tender
    • Bandl’s ring is felt (Retraction ring)
    • Fetal heart rate absent
  • Vaginal exam
    • Vagina feels hot and dry
    • Cervix hangs loosely like a curtain
    • Caput +++
    • Moulding +++
    • Head feels jammed in the pelvis
  • The mainstay of management will be to start IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Emergency LSCS is the rule in Obstructed labor even in a dead fetus

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Craniotomy: This is a destructive fetal operation which is not preferred anymore even in a non-viable fetus/ dead fetus. It can be done if ffacilities for immediate cesarean are not available.  The main indications for fetal craniotomy are:

 

  • Cephalic presentation with obstructed labour
  • Hydrocephalus in a living fetus
  • Interlocking head of twins
  • Aftercoming head of breech

 

Option B. Decapitation: It is severing of the fetal head from the trunk. It is a destructive operation and again is not preferred unless facilities for emergency LSCS are not available or in exceptional circumstances. Indications are

 

  • Neglected shoulder with a dead fetus
  • Locked twins

 

Option D. Forceps extraction: Instrumental delivery is contra-indicated in obstructed labor. CPD should be ruled out prior to applying an instrument (Forceps or vacuum)

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of obstructed labor, an emergency cesarean section is the recommended management, even if the fetus is deceased.

 

Ref: Page no 421, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: After successful delivery of the baby, the obstetrician witnesses that the episiotomy performed has extended backwards beyond the perineal body. Which among the following structures is likely to be injured in this case? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) External anal sphincter

 

Explanation

 

  • Obstetrical Anal Sphincter Injuries (OASIS) include third and fourth-degree lacerations.
  • Third-degree lacerations involve the external anal sphincter:
    • 3A: Less than 50% of the external anal sphincter torn.
    • 3B: More than 50% of the external anal sphincter torn.
    • 3C: Both the external and internal anal sphincter torn.
  • Fourth-degree lacerations extend to the rectal mucosa.
  • In the scenario mentioned, the episiotomy has extended backward beyond the perineal body, likely damaging the anal sphincter and potentially the anal mucosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Ischiocavernosus: This muscle is located more laterally and is less likely to be involved in a backward extension of the episiotomy.

 

Option C: Bulbospongiosus: This muscle is located in the perineal body and is usually affected by a standard episiotomy, but not specifically by a backward extension beyond the perineal body.

 

Option D: Urethral sphincter: This sphincter is located anteriorly and is not involved in a backward extension of the episiotomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases where an episiotomy extends backward beyond the perineal body, the external anal sphincter is the structure most likely to be injured.

 

Ref: Page no 1307, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: During management of a labor in case of shoulder dystocia, a maneuver was done as shown below. This maneuver is known as? (FMGE jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cleidotomy

 

Explanation:

 

Cleidotomy is intentional fetal clavicular fracture, which reduces the diameter of the shoulder girdle that requires to pass through the birth canal.

 

The table below enlists the manoeuvres used in the management of shoulder dystocia including the options A B C D

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cleidotomy is an intentional fetal clavicular fracture performed to reduce the shoulder girdle diameter in cases of shoulder dystocia.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th Edition Page 469-470

choices.text: History of lower transverse cesarean section in last two pregnancies

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for the induction of labor? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heart disease

 

Explanation:

 

  • Cardiovascular diseases are not a contraindication for vaginal delivery. In fact, NVD is preferred in heart disease patients. The second stage of labour is cut short with the use of instrumental vaginal delivery like forceps or ventouse assisted vaginal delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pelvic tumor: Pelvic tumor if diagnosed may interfere with normal labor and needs to be evaluated before deciding the mode of delivery

 

Option B. Herpes infection:  Active herpes is an absolute contra-indication to a normal delivery due to the high viral shedding in the lesions and increased risk of neonatal herpes.

 

Option D. History of lower transverse cesarean section in last two pregnancies: History of 2 or more previous cesareans is also a contra-indication to a vaginal delivery and hence induction is not done

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cardiovascular diseases are not a contraindication for vaginal delivery, and NVD is preferred in heart disease patients.

 

Ref: Page no 332, Dc Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: In which of the following will you NOT do induction of labor? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Central Placenta Previa

 

Explanation:

 

Induction of labor involves starting labor artificially in a patient who is not already in labor, usually to expedite delivery due to various maternal or fetal indications such as fetal growth restriction, post-term pregnancy, oligohydramnios, or preeclampsia. The goal of induction is to achieve vaginal delivery.

 

However, induction is contraindicated in situations where vaginal delivery is not possible or safe, as in central placenta previa, where the placenta completely covers the cervical os. Attempting vaginal delivery in this situation can lead to severe hemorrhage as contractions begin. Therefore, a cesarean section is indicated for central placenta previa to avoid the risk of bleeding and ensure the safety of both the mother and the fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oligohydramnios: Induction is indicated to avoid complications from low amniotic fluid.

 

Option C. Hypertension: Induction is recommended at 37 weeks for mild preeclampsia and at 34 weeks for severe preeclampsia to prevent maternal and fetal complications.

 

Option D. PROM: Induction is required if labor does not start spontaneously to prevent infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Induction of labor is contraindicated in central placenta previa due to the risk of severe hemorrhage, necessitating a cesarean section for safe delivery.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant G3P2L2 woman presented to OBG department at 36 weeks of amenorrhea. Ultrasound shows that the fetus is in a transverse lie. The liquor is adequate, the placenta is normal, and she has no gross anomaly. Both her previous deliveries were normal vaginal deliveries. How will you manage this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) External cephalic version

 

In this situation, external cephalic version should be attempted.

 

Management of Transverse lie –

 

 

Absolute Contraindications of ECV:

 

  • Placenta Previa
  • Contracted Pelvis
  • Multiple Pregnancy
  • Hyperextended head
  • Uterine Anomaly
  • Dead fetus
  • Distressed fetus
  • Denied consent

 

Complications of ECV:

 

  • Abruption
  • Rupture of membranes
  • Preterm labour.
  • Fetal distress.
  • Cord presentation or prolapse
  • Entangling of the cord around the fetus.
  • Isoimmunization in Rh-negative mothers due to feto-maternal transfusion.
  • Induction of labor is contraindicated in Transverse lie.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cesarean section: While a cesarean section is the best and safest method of delivery in cases of persistent transverse or oblique lie, it is not the first-line management in this situation where ECV can be attempted.

 

Option C. Expectant management: Waiting for spontaneous correction is not recommended at 36 weeks with a transverse lie, as it may not occur, and could lead to complications.

 

Option D. Induction of labor: Inducing labor in a transverse lie position is contraindicated as it can lead to complications such as cord prolapse and obstructed labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

External cephalic version should be attempted between 36 and 37 weeks of gestation for a fetus in a transverse lie if there are no contraindications.

questions.text: Shoulder dystocia is defined as delay in delivery of shoulders after delivery of head by? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 60 sec

 

Shoulder dystocia is technically defined as a delay in delivery of shoulders for more than 60 seconds after delivery of the head. 

 

Once the head is delivered and external rotation/restitution occurs, if the anterior shoulder doesn't deliver with gentle traction, maneuvers to relieve shoulder dystocia should be initiated immediately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Shoulder dystocia has two definitions:

 

  1. Technical: Delay in shoulder delivery >60 seconds after head delivery
  2. Practical: Need for additional maneuvers beyond gentle traction to deliver shoulders after head delivery
  3. Turtle Sign: Seen in Shoulder dystocia

choices.text: Remove placenta and reposition the uterus
Put uterus inside without removing the placenta
Shift to OT and insert the uterus back

questions.text: A patient has just delivered a full-term baby and developed uterine inversion with the placenta still attached. What is the immediate next step? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Put uterus inside without removing the placenta

 

Immediate management of uterine inversion involves repositioning the uterus before removing the placenta to prevent severe bleeding and shock.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Remove placenta and reposition the uterus: Removing the placenta before repositioning the uterus can lead to massive hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Shift to OT and insert the uterus back: Immediate manual repositioning is crucial before shifting to an operating theatre.

 

Option D. Start Oxytocin: Oxytocin is used after the uterus is repositioned to encourage contraction, not before.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of uterine inversion, the uterus should be repositioned with the placenta still attached to avoid significant bleeding, followed by medical management for uterine contraction.

questions.text: Identify this instrument used in the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Piper forceps

 

Piper forceps are specifically designed for the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech presentations. Their unique shape allows them to grasp the head of the baby gently and guide it through the birth canal without applying excessive pressure. The long, curved shanks of Piper forceps are particularly adapted for use when the baby is in breech position, making them the most appropriate tool for this scenario.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wrigley forceps: These are outlet forceps used when the fetal head is at +3 station, fully or nearly fully rotated. They are not designed for use in breech presentations.

 

 

Option C. Kielland forceps: These are rotational forceps used when the fetal head is high and unrotated. They are meant for complex cases where rotation of the head is necessary, not for the aftercoming head in breech.

 

 

Option D. Dass forceps: These are low forceps used when the fetal head is at +2 station. They are not suitable for the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech as they are not designed for such specific maneuvering.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Piper forceps are the instrument of choice for the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech presentations due to their specialized design that facilitates safe extraction.

questions.text: Banana sign and lemon sign are seen in? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NTD

 

Banana sign and lemon sign are ultrasound findings typically associated with neural tube defects (NTD), more specifically spina bifida.

 

  • Banana sign: This refers to the excessive curvature of the cerebellum, which appears compressed and curved, resembling a banana.
  • Lemon sign: This is characterized by the pinching of the frontal bones of the fetal skull, causing it to appear like a lemon when viewed from the front. These signs are indicative of the changes in intracranial pressure and structure caused by spina bifida.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anencephaly: This condition involves the absence of a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp, and is often described as having a "frog-like" face due to the absence of the cranial vault.

 

Option C. Down syndrome: Down syndrome has various ultrasound markers, but these are typically subtle and referred to as soft tissue markers, not including the banana or lemon signs.

 

Option D. Duodenal atresia: This condition is characterized by the "double bubble" sign on ultrasound, indicating a blockage in the duodenum, and is not associated with the banana or lemon signs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Banana sign and lemon sign are ultrasound findings seen in neural tube defects (NTD), particularly in cases of spina bifida.

questions.text: A primigravida is in the 2nd stage of labor for 2 hours. The head is at +3 with caput present and the fetal heart rate (FHR) is dropping to 90 bpm. What is the best way to deliver the head? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Outlet forceps

 

In this scenario, the patient is a primigravida (a woman pregnant for the first time) who is in the second stage of labor, which has been ongoing for 2 hours. The second stage of labor in a primigravida can be allowed up to 3 hours if the mother and fetus are stable. However, in this case, the fetal heart rate has dropped to 90 bpm, indicating fetal distress, and the head is at +3 station, meaning it is very low in the pelvis, almost at the pelvic floor.

 

  • Outlet forceps are specifically designed for situations where the fetal head is at +3 station or lower. The head is visible at the introitus without separating the labia, and delivery needs to be expedited due to fetal distress. In this case, the application of outlet forceps is preferred because it allows for a quicker delivery compared to other methods. This is critical when there is evidence of fetal distress, as time is of the essence to reduce the risk of hypoxia.
  • Mid cavity forceps are used when the fetal head is higher in the pelvis, typically at 0 to +1 station. This option is not suitable in this case because the head is much lower, at +3 station.
  • Low forceps are used when the head is at +2 station, slightly higher than in this scenario. They are not appropriate when the head is at +3 station.
  • Ventouse (vacuum extraction) can be used at various stations, but it is generally slower to apply compared to forceps. Additionally, the presence of caput (swelling of the fetal scalp) can make it difficult to achieve the necessary suction for effective vacuum delivery. Therefore, outlet forceps are preferred in this scenario to ensure a quicker and more effective delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mid cavity forceps: Incorrect because they are used when the head is at a higher station, typically 0 to +1, and the head is not yet at the pelvic floor.

 

Option B. Low forceps: Incorrect because they are more suitable when the head is at +2 station, not when it is already at +3 station.

 

Option D. Ventouse (vacuum extraction): While it could technically be used, it is not the best choice here because of the fetal distress and the presence of caput, which may hinder the effective application of the vacuum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of fetal distress with the fetal head at +3 station, outlet forceps are the preferred method of assisted delivery due to their speed and effectiveness, particularly when caput is present.
